p.s: Sonnet 138 written by William ShakespearShakespeare engages with the topic of love and lifeslife's beauty.
The author expresses how to speaker and the lover conquer the ravages of life, aging and lying.
Shakespeare signifies the importance of trust in a relationship.
Shakespeare starts his sonnet with a guiding thesis.
The thesis outlines what happens when the speakersspeaker's lover swears she is made of truth.
(l. 1) The speaker gives a direct answer by stating he does believe her even though he knows she/he lies.
It highlights his strong devotion towards his lover.
In the second quatrain (l. 5-9) is an explinationexplanation deluding to the thesis why the speaker believes his lover tells the truth.
He proclaims, in order to conquer the ravages in a relationship both have o lie or even relierely on ignoring each other's false claims.
Right at the beginning of the third quatrain ShakespearShakespeare invokes two guiding rhetorical questions outlining, wherefore two people ignore each other's flaws.
After the speaker deotes, loves best habit is in blind trust, a volta, a change of perspective follows.
The volta, after line ten outlines, none of the things mentioned before matter beause nothing changes the way the two beloved people feel for each other.
Moreover, it signifies that trust and love goes far beyond their flaws and insecurities.
